ParentCompanyName: Burlington Resources Oil & Gas Company, L.P.

_prev_prog_3.Description: This is an OSHA PSM facility.  There is an automated emergency shutdown system which triggers isolation of portions of the process to limit the quantity of H2S release.  The shutdown system also depressures the equipment safely to the flare.  There are local area H2S monitors which will signal a release.  Operators are trained under PSM to safely deal with and mitigate H2S releases.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality and Wyoming OHS

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This facility is constructed in accordance with ASME code requirements, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  The facility is operated and maintained in accordance with OSHA 1910.119, PSM requirements.  A written emergency plan is in place which includes coordination and response by the Fremont County Emergency Management, if required.

The Lost Cabin Gas Plant removes carbon dioxide (CO2), sulfur compounds, and water from natural gas in order to meet pipeline specifications for product sales.  The raw gas is cooled and contacted with a solvent (SELEXOL) to remove contaminates in each of three gas processing trains.  One of these gas processing trains contains H2S above the RMP threshold quantities and is considered a Program 3 process.  A propane refrigeration system is utilized in each train to cool the solvent to improve its performance.  Each of the three propane refrigeration systems is equipped with compressors, piping valves and a receiver tank that contains approximately 50,000 pounds of propane stored as a liquid under pressure.  Each of these propane systems is considered a Program 1 RMP process.

Train 3, the Program 3 process, is a gas processing facility with many vessels interconnecting by pipe.  There are several active mitigation devices in place to minimize a potential release of H2S.  The worst case release for Train 3 would discharge approximately 22,000 pounds of H2S.  According to the RMP Comp software, the distance to the endpoint from Train 3 for toxic conditions is 8.7 miles.  There are two small towns (Lysite and Lost Cabin, Wyoming) that are within the radius of exposure.  The combined population of these towns is approximately 90.  The town of Lysite has public receptors in addition to homes such as a store, restaurant, and library several small businesses.  There are no environmental receptors within the radius to endpoint.

The three propane receiver tanks are separated by at least 400 feet of

distance.  Failure of the tank wall of any of these three receiver tanks will trigger a worst case RMP scenario.  Since the tanks are isolated from one another, each tank is evaluated independently for the worst case scenario and would release 50,000 pounds of propane.  According to the RMP Comp software, the distance to the endpoint from a receiver tank for 1 psi overpressure is 0.3 miles.  There are no private homes, public receptors, or environmental receptors within the distance to the endpoint form any of the three receiver tanks.  

Train 3 is a new facility, and operations are scheduled to begin by the end of August 2002.  Therefore, there have been no releases of H2S or accidents cause by a release of H2S from Train 3 (RMP Program 3 process).  The Lost Cabin Gas Plant has never had an accident involving propane (RMP Program 1 process) that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place. This facility complies with ASME code requirements, OSHA PSM, and state and local codes and regulations.

The plant personnel are equipped to control incipient fires and other emergencies.  Offensive efforts to fight fires beyond the incipient stage will be the responsibility of off-site fire departments.  They are authorized to take whatever actions are deemed necessary to protect lives and property.  In the event of an emergency involving these propane systems, the first line of defense will be to handle incipient type fires with plant personnel.  If the personnel on duty can not adequately stabilize and control the incident or if a fire has grown beyond the incipient stage, then emergency callout procedures will be initiated per the facility Emergency Response Plan.  The emergency callout procedure contains phone numbers of local emergency response agencies, such as Fremont County Emergency Management ? who has been advised and educated on potential events that might require their assistance.

No revisions are currently sche

duled for our safety policies; however, continuous improvement programs are utilized consistent with the plant Incident Investigation Procedure and Wyoming OHS standards contained in 29 CFR Section 1910.120.
